Colin =96

You are certainly correct, neither the original SharpNEAT nor my=

Braille version of the OCR experiment, are proper OCR.  Rather they
are fi=
xed pattern classification problems.  I decided to make a
version of your e=
xperiment because it was straightforward to
understand and modify.  The Exp=
eriment View window, showing the
characters as they are correctly or incorr=
ectly classified, is
interesting to watch.  One can cheer the networks on a=
s they learn to
distinguish between three or two dots in a column.  The fit=
ness
function is also a no brainer =96 the character is either right or
wro=
ng.  You are also correct that Braille characters are essentially
3x2 dots.=
  I put some white space around and between the dots to make
the characters=
 "prettier".

The Nero world is way out of my league and even the complicat=
ions of
Tic-Tac-Toe have been surprising to read about.  This little patter=
n
classification system seemed just right for initially learning about
NEAT=
.  I am having a great time adjusting the various search
parameters and slo=
wly digging into the network code to see how they
work.

Thanks again for t=
he work you put into SharpNEAT.

Carl
